Lesson Narrative

The mathematical purpose of this lesson is to understand that the relationship between variables can be, but is not always, a causal relationship. A causal relationship is one in which a change in one of the variables directly causes a change in the other variable. The work of this lesson connects to previous work because students interpreted the relationship between two variables using the correlation coefficient. The work of this lesson connects to upcoming work because students will analyze bivariate data and draw conclusions from their analysis.

When students determine that there is a causal relationship, they are attending to precision because they are refining their language to be more precise. When students analyze the relationship between two variables to determine whether they have a causal relationship, they are modeling with mathematics.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Describe (orally and in writing) the strength and sign of the relationship between two variables.
  • Investigate the relationship between two variables to analyze whether or not the relationship is causal.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Determine whether or not there is a causal relationship.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

4(A) calculate, using technology, the correlation coefficient between two quantitative variables and interpret this quantity as a measure of the strength of the linear association.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

4(B) compare and contrast association and causation in real-world problems.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Required Materials

  • None

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 3.6.1: Describing the Relationship between Variables
  • 3.6.2: Describing How Two Variables Are Related
    • 3.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 3.6.3: Using the Term Causal Relationship
    • 3.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 3.6.4: Determining the Type of Relationship

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 3.6.5: Practice.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

  • correlation coefficient
  • residual
  • negative relationship
  • positive relationship
  • strong relationship
  • weak relationship

New Vocabulary

  • casual relationship
